Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Fundamental Studies on the Separation Mechanisms of Porous Polymer Monoliths
Award.AbstractNarration:
Professor Michelle M. Bushey of Trinity University is supported by the Chemical Measurement and Imaging (CMI) Program in the Division of Chemistry to conduct a fundamental study of the interactions of analytes and the mobile phase with organic polymer monolith stationary phases in HPLC and capillary electrochromatography (CEC). The objective is to derive a basic understanding of the separation mechanisms with organic polymer monolith stationary phases. Thermodynamic properties and diffusion coefficients will be measured as a function of retention factor for different analytes, different mobile phases and different acrylate and methacrylate monolithic polymers.

A thorough understanding of these interactions will impact the development of efficient stationary phases for practical chromatographic separations. Modeling of chromatographic separations with conventional stationary phases has resulted in great improvement in separation performance. The lack of a parallel basic understanding of chromatography with polymer monolith stationary phases hampered the development and limited the broad acceptance of these unique analytical separation media. Undergraduate students will be trained in analytical separation science and technology in an ethnically diverse undergraduate institution.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The specific goal of this project was to further basic fundamental understanding of the behavior of organic polymer monoliths used as stationary phases in both capillary electrochromatography (CEC) and High Performance Liquid Chromatography (HPLC) systems. This type of stationary phase is distinctly different from the silica particle based phases traditionally used in CEC and HPLC. While these polymeric phases offer many intriguing capabilities, they are much less well understood than particle based phases. Studies included measuring various analyte diffusion coefficients as a function of retention factor. The diffusion studies show that the lauryl acrylate polymer monolith exhibits linear Knox behavior. This is unlike any other report for other stationary phases. The slope of this plot is also reduced compared to other types of phases. The linear behavior is attributed to the reduced internal porosity of the polymers. The internal porosity is also influenced by the use of electroosmotic flow carriers in the polymer preparation. Other retention factor experiments were conducted as a function of temperature to determine the enthalpy and entropy of retention of analytes on these polymeric phases. These phases exhibit linear van’t Hoff behavior when used in CEC. The linearity indicates in part that the phase ratio is constant across the investigated temperature range. Analyte partitioning is enthalpically driven. There is a substantial decrease in entropy associated with partitioning. A scanning electron microscope was used to measure the size of various polymer features. Measurements were made in situ for polymers cast in fused silica capillaries. A method using an in situ ruler for the measurement of polymer features was adapted. The PI, postdoctoral team members and undergraduates have given 25 presentations at national and international conferences and symposia on these results. Most presentations have been given by undergraduates.

 

The broader impacts of this work arise from Trinity University’s role as an undergraduate institution with research active faculty. Nineteen undergraduates and one high school student have worked on this project. Ten summer (full or partial) stipends were provided by this award to these students. All students were trained in analytical methods of developing hypotheses, data collection, documentation, analysis, reporting (oral and written formats). Students had many opportunities to present the results of their work at national professional conferences. Six former students are pursuing graduate studies in STEM areas. Two are pursuing pharmacy degrees. Two are or will pursue medical degrees. Five others have yet to graduate. This was a demographically diverse team, and eleven of the 20 young researchers were women. Two postdoctoral associates are now in tenure track positions as analytical chemists in primarily undergraduate institutions. Both have started undergraduate research programs. While associated with this work, they each had the opportunity to supervise students in a research lab, teach in instructional programs, participate in faculty development activities, and otherwise prepare themselves for tenure track positions at primarily undergraduate institutions. A visiting researcher will assume a temporary teaching position at a primarily undergraduate institution in the fall of 2016. She had the same professional development opportunities as the postdoctoral associates.
